Authors:
Alcindo Silva Martins Jr, Cassia Monica Sakuragui, Anibal
Alves Carvalho Jr
Title:
Coleosporium vernoniae, a Pucciniales species widely
distributed by the three largest Brazilian Biomes: focus based on
molecular marker sequence
Abstract:
Coleosporium vernoniae is a species morphologically
circumscribed and widely distributed throughout the Americas. It has a
pleomorphic life cycle, with the gametic and zygotic stages found on
Pinus spp., and the clonal and meiotic stages on Asteraceae genera
(Elephanthopus and Vernonia, mainly). In Brazil, this species occurs in
areas of different biomes, is widely distributed and has wide tolerance
to variable environmental factors or may constitute physiological or
even species complexes. Thus, the objective of this work was to collect
specimens of C. vernoniae in the three largest Brazilian biomes, to
access molecular information from the nuc rDNA fragment ITS2-28S and to
retrieve lineages corresponding to the Amazon, Cerrado and Atlantic
Forest. Samples of Elephantopus moliis parasitized by C. vernoninae were
collected in representative areas of the Amazon, Cerrado and Atlantic
Forest. The 5.8S-ITS2-28S nuc rDNA fragment from the collected samples
was accessed and compared to two data sets composed of sequences from
Coleosporium species and one from Chrysomyxa (external group). The
first, referring to the complete ITS marker (ITS1-5.8S-ITS2) and the
other to the marker 28S (partial 5.8S-ITS2-28S), available in online
database. Maximum Likelihood and Bayesian Inference analyzes were used
to recover the relationships between the collected specimens. All the
analyzes, from the different data sets, present the C. vernoniae samples
grouped in a single clade without definition of lineages corresponding
to the biomes. This shows that in the same host and with the definition
that the molecular marker allows, it is a species with predominance of
the clonal stage of the life cycle, high dispersion capacity and, in
this way, accompanies the host distribution.
